s.text: He had a decade of writing his novel behind him and almost three more ahead of him.
Before the group succeeds in reaching him, an assassin shoots the racist Sunraider from the Senate gallery.
Before the group succeeds in reaching him, an assassin shoots the racist Sunraider from the Senate gallery.

Without adding a word (other than the title Juneteenth ), he has culled a nugget that gives a sense of what Ellison was up to all those years without harming any of the alternative conceptions of the work that are bound to emerge.
Ellison's readers (and Ellison's publisher) wanted the legendary second novel they were sure had to be buried in the papers somewhere.
Ellison's readers (and Ellison's publisher) wanted the legendary second novel they were sure had to be buried in the papers somewhere.
Ellison's readers (and Ellison's publisher) wanted the legendary second novel they were sure had to be buried in the papers somewhere.
Indeed, a great, unfinished work can be more fascinating than a finished one because of the way the reader is drawn into the artistic process.
In a curious way, the unfinished state of the novel complements the inherent and intentional incompleteness of the underlying story.
In a curious way, the unfinished state of the novel complements the inherent and intentional incompleteness of the underlying story.

In a curious way, the unfinished state of the novel complements the inherent and intentional incompleteness of the underlying story.
When Ralph Ellison died in 1994, he left behind thousands of pages of drafts and notes for the book he had been working on for 40 years--and a terrible dilemma.
Think of William Faulkner, whose characters often appear and reappear in his various novels and stories.
